lines.text: Peter, what are your exact feelings for me?
Those of a devoted son, Wendy.

[Annoyed]
I thought so.
[She sits further away from him]
You're so strange. Tinker Bell's just the same. There's something she wants to be to me, but she says it's not my mother.
[Tinker Bell replies "You silly ass" in fairy language]
I almost agree with her!

Second to the right, and straight on till morning. That is the way to Neverland. If you close your eyes, you will see a pool of lovely, pale colors. If you squeeze them tighter, the pool will take on different shapes, and the colors will become brighter - so bright, that in a moment they'll go on fire. And in that moment, just before they do, you will see Neverland, a magic island on whose shores children are forever at play.
[first lines]

Some say that as we grow up, we become different people at different ages, but I don't believe this. I think we remain the same throughout, merely passing in these years from one room, to another, but always in the same house. If we unlock the rooms of the far past, we can look in and see ourselves beginning to become you and me.

[dressed up like their parents and dancing]
One-two-three, one-two-three, one-two-three, one-two-three.

[singing]
I'm flying... / Look at me, / Way up high, / Suddenly, / Here am I, / I'm flying.

But Peter threw me hand to a crocodile, who happened to be passing by. And that croc liked the taste of me hand so much, he's followed me ever since. From land to land, from sea to sea, he follows the ship - licking his lips for the rest of me.
Well, in a way, it is a sort of compliment.

[bonking Smee on the head]
Well, I want no such compliment.
The game is up. Those boys have found a mother.
What's a mother?
[Hook bonks Smee on the head]

[singing]
I gotta crow. / I'm just the cleverest fella / 'Twas ever my fortune to know.
No, Nana. Don't disturb the master. He uses your house as his home, out of remorse. I'll wake him when it's time for his dinner.
SHHHHHHHHH!
Split me infinitives, but 'tis me hour of triumph!

[pausing, out of breath, during the duel with Peter]
'Tisn't fair! I say it as though it were my last breath - it isn't fair! Pan, who and what art thou?
I am youth. I am joy. I am freedom!

[singing]
You're ready?
Ready!
Ready!
Ready!

[singing]
Don't forget, don't be slow/ready set, here we go/Wendy, Michael, John... Tinkerbell, come on/Hurry up after me for soon I will be gone, I'm flying!
Bird might be omen!
Good or bad omen?

[shrugs]
Ancient Indian proverb... when in doubt... RUN!
Well if you are Captain Hook, then what am I?
A codfish.

[Wendy's about to shoot the Indians]
Don't shoot! We're friends now.

[confused]
Friends?
I saved Tiger Lily's life in the forest, and she saved my life.

No little children love me. I'm told they play at Peter Pan, and the strongest always chooses to be Peter. They force the baby to be Hook. The baby - that's where the canker gnaws. I'm told they find Smee lovable. How can I break it to him that they find him lovable?

[Tinkerbell tells him what's happened]
The Indians have been defeated? And Wendy and the boys have been captured by the pirates? I'll rescue her! I'll rescue her!
[Tinkerbell notices the poisoned medicine]
What? That's just my medicine.
[Tinkerbell protests]
Poison? Nonsense, who could've poisoned it? I promised Wendy I'd take that, and I'm going to just as soon as I sharpen my dagger.
[Tinkerbell drinks the medicine]
Tink! You drunk my medicine!
[Tinkerbell flies about slowly and grows dim]

What's the matter with you? It was poison, wasn't it? You drank it to save my life. Tink? Dear Tink! You're dying! Your voice is so low now I can hardly hear you. What's that? You believe that you could get well again... if children believed in fairies.

[the boys present Peter with their "bird"]
Wendy! With an arrow in her heart! This is no bird, it's a lady!
A lady?
I was bringing her here to be your mother, and now you've killed her!
Peter, how old are you?
I don't know. I ran away from home the day I was born.
Ran away? Why?
Because I heard father and mother discussing what I was to be when I became a man. I want to always be a little boy and have fun! So I ran away, and I've lived a long time among the fairies.
Peter! You really know fairies?

Yes, but they're nearly all dead now. You see, Wendy, when the first baby laughed for the very first time, the laugh broke up into a thousand pieces of light, and they all went skipping about, and that was the beginning of fairies. So now every time a new baby is born, its first laugh becomes a fairy.
Peter, why did you come to our nursery window?
To hear a story. None of us know any stories.
How perfectly awful.
Wendy, your mother was telling you such a lovely story.
Oh? Which story is it?
It was about the prince... and he couldn't find the lady who wore the glass slipper.
Ohhh... that was Cinderella, he found her, and they lived happily ever after.
I'm glad!
[dashes to the window]
Where are you going?
To tell the other boys!
Oh please don't go! I know lots of stories!
Do you?
Oh, the stories I could tell the other boys!
Liza, We're pretending we're Mother and Father and we're going to the ball tonight, come play!
Always playing games? I have much more important things to do than play make believe and *dahn*-cing.
What are you doing in my old hat?
We're doing an act.
Yes, we're playing you and Father, I'm Father. A little less noise there, a little less noise!
Mother, they never let me play Father, and they never let me dance.
Well, we'll soon fix that.
[takes John's hat off and puts it on Michael]
There. May I have this dance, Mr. Darling?
George, we must keep Nana.
[whispers]
I'll tell you why.
[to the kids]
Get ready for bed, children, now run along...
[children leave]
George, tonight I saw a face at the window.
Face at the window, two floors up?
It was the face of a little boy, he was trying to get in.
That's impossible.
But that's not the first time I've seen that boy.
Oh?

The first time was a week ago, I remember because it was Nana's night off... I was sitting over there by the fire, when suddenly I felt a draft, as though the window were open... I looked... and I saw that boy in the room, I screamed. Just then Nana came in and sprang at him at once, the boy leapt through the window, Nana closed it quickly, but it was too late to catch him.
I thought so.
But wait! *He* escaped, but his shadow hadn't time to get out. I hid it...
[takes it out of Wendy's dresser drawer]
I rolled it up, and here it is.
Aha! Hmmm... Well, I don't think it's anyone we know, though he does look a scoundrel.
You know, George, I think he comes back trying to get his shadow.
I dare say...

But wait, I haven't told you all. The boy was not quite alone; he was accompanied by... Well, I don't know how to describe it... by a bolt of light no bigger than my fist that darted around the room, like a living thing.
This is most unusual.
George, what can it mean?
What indeed? What indeed?

[about Neverland]
Peter, what does it look like?
It's an island, Wendy.
A large one?
No, quite small, and nicely crammed, so there's hardly any room between one adventure and the next.
Oh, it sounds wonderful. Who else lives there, Peter?
The Lost Boys.
Who are they?
They're the children that fall out of their carriages when the nurse is looking the other way. If they're not claimed in 7 days, they're sent far away to Neverland... I'm Captain.

[singing]
I have a place where dreams are born / And time is never planned. / It's not on any chart / You must find it with your heart. / Never-Never Land. / It might be miles beyond the moon, / Or right there where you stand. / Just keep an open mind, / And then suddenly you'll find / Never-Never Land. / You'll have a treasure if you stay there / More precious far than gold. / For once you have found your way there / You can never, never grow old. / So that's my home where dreams are born / And time is never planned. / Just think of lovely things / And your heart will fly on wings / Forever... in Never-Never Land.
Peter Pan is the sun and the moon and the stars!
[all cheer]
Peter Pan is the love of delight!
[all cheer]
Peter Pan is the bravest and strongest of all boys!
[all cheer]
Yes, I know. I don't say it to boast, it's because I cannot tell a lie.
You won't forget to come for me, Peter. Please - please don't forget.

[singing]
So naturally... /When I discover the cleverness of a remarkable me... /How can I hide it when deep down inside it just tickles me so?/Then I gotta let go... /And crow.
Hello, Wendy!
Peter!
Where's John?
He's not here anymore.
Is Michael asleep?
Yes! No! That's not Michael.
Is it a new one?
Yes!
Boy or girl?
It's a girl.
What's her name?
Jane.
Jane.
Peter, are you expecting me to fly away with you?
Of course! That's why I came. Have you forgotten it's spring cleaning time?
I can't come. I've forgotten how to fly.
I'll teach you again.
No, Peter! Don't waste your fairy dust on me.
What's the matter?
I'll turn up the lights and you can see for yourself.
No! Don't turn up the lights! What is it?
I'm old Peter.
Old? What do you mean old?
I'm ever so much more than 20. I grew up a long time ago.

[to Mrs. Darling]
I warn you of this, Mother, that if this tie does not go round my neck, we don't go out to dinner tonight. And if we don't go out to dinner tonight, I never go to the office again. And if I never go to the office again, you and I will starve, and our children will be flung into the streets.
Then, one night, a long time after, when it was once more spring cleaning time, the stars blew open the nursery windows.
No! By carbonate of soda, no!
There oughta be a fairy for every girl and boy.
Oughta be? Isn't there?
Oh, no. Children know such a lot now. Soon they don't believe. And every time a child says "I don't believe in fairies", there's a fairy someplace that falls down dead.
You promised not to.
I couldn't help it. I'm a married woman now.
No, you're not! No, you're not!
Yes! And the little girl in that bed is my child.
No, she's not! No, she's not!
